bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, November 6, 1900
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

p.add: INDEX BUREAU REC'D DEC 8 '00 DEPT OF STATE
Copy to Mr referring to his letters of Sept 12 & 17 & our reply of Sept 26 1900

div1.p: No. 52. Consular. Legation of the United States. Monrovia Liberia, Nov. 6, 1900.

p.add: Aus. by form to Hon. C. E. Littlefeild Dec 13, 1900. further acknowledged December 31st 1900 see his to. 52

div1.p: Hon. David J Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.
Subject. Correspondence, relative to the Estate of the late Anranus M. Miller, late of Harper (Cape Palmas) Liberia
No. 52. Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, Nov. 6 1900.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: Referring to my No. 51, "Consulor," Octo. 26, 1900. I have the honor to say that: carefully searching the records and files of this Legation, touching the correspondence between this Legation, the State and other Departments, of the Liberian Government, and other individuals in this country and the United States, relative the estate of the late Anranus M. Miller, deceased, late of Harper, (Cape Palmas) Liberia; I have found the originals, of which copies are
are, herewith, inclosed.

In note No. 1. Oct. 31, 1892, of Wm. D. McKoy Esq. to E. Warneke, giving number of Treasury Orders &c., you will take notice that the apparently erased No. 75 (No. 74) written in red ink is a faithful copy of the Record, whatever it may represent.

2. I regret to say we find no record of Note of Wm. D. McKoy Esq., rewritting the $50 order, acknowledged having been received by Hon. H. A. Williams, Secretary of Treasury, in his note of January 4, 1893, as per inclosed copy.

We, however, are inclined to believe that the $50.-- One General Government Order No. 40, undoubtedly added after the fooling up of the several Treasury Orders, amounting to $1001.75; is the $50. order of the

the Hon. H. A. Williams, Secretary of the Treasury Jan. 4, 1893, (as per inclosed copy), which appears to have been added to the original sum. Note No. 1 of Oct. 31, 1892. See note of Wm. D. McKoy Esq., of March 25, 1893 to Mrs. A. M. Miller Newcastle, ME, in which he, undoubtedly, refers to the $50. Treasury Order, of the Hon. H. A> Williams, Secretary of the Treasury. Jan. 4, 1893.
We find no record of any correspondence, touching this case, between Wm. H. Heard Esq., and any other party, excepting a receipt from F. O. Thorn, for $456.59, in Treasury Order- Jan. 1898.
3. I inclose, herewith, a correct copy of the Act of the Liberian Legislature session 1893-4, referred to by Hon. H. A. Williams, Secretary of the Treasury, in his Note
Note, of February 22, 1894 to Vice Consul General B. Y. Payne.

Hoping the foregoing may be of some service, as well as information, relative to this can and thinking it very advisable that F. O. Thorn Esq., who is the senior senator from Maryland county, be required to turn over the Treasury Order for $456.59, (in his possession) to this Legation, for collection, if possible.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant, Owen L. W. Smith, M. R. and C. General.
Inclosures.

1. Wm. D. McKoy, No. 1, Oct. 31, 1892 to E. Warneke Esq. Cape Palmas. 2. Wm. D. McKoy, No. 19 Dec. 5, 1892 to Hon. G. W. Gibson, Sec. of State. 3. Wm. D. McKoy, Mar. 25, 1893, to Mrs. A. M. Miller, Newcastle, ME
(see page 7)

4. Hon. H. A. Williams Jan. 4, 1893, to Wm. D. McKoy. 5. Wm. D. McKoy, No. 23, April 24, 1893, to Hon. G. W. Gibson, Sec of State. 6. B. Y. Payne, Aug. 19, 1893, to Mrs. E. A. Miller, Newcastle, ME. 7. B. Y. Payne, Feb'y 21, 1894 to Hon. H. A. Williams Sec Treasury. 8. Hon. H. A. Williams, Sec Treasury to B. Y. Payne. Feb'y 22, 1894. 9. F. O. Thorn Receipt, Jan. 1898, to W. H. Heard. 10. Copy Act of Liberian Legislature session 1893-4.
Copy

Received from Honorable W. A. Heard Consul General of the United States at Monrovia Liberia, the sum of Four Hundred Fifty Six 59/100 Dollars in Liberia government Bills on a/c Mifs Winifred Miller of Newcastle Maine U.S.A.
F. O. Thorne Monrovia January 1898.
Copy
Treasury Department, Monrovia, Feb'y, 22, 1894.
Hon. B. Y. Payne, U. S. Vice Consul General, Monrovia.

Sir: I have received your note of yesterday, referring to the amt. of $598 15/100 in Maryland County obligations, belonging to the estate of the late A. M. Miller. I beg to say that by a resolution of the last Legislature the Department is authorized to receive in been of the currency arising from the essne of 3% Bonds &c of all description. If it should suit you, the amt. of obligations in your possession, will be taken up by the Department for currency on account of the next accumulation of this money. Payment otherwise than by this
this means would have to be by the check of the Superintendent of Maryland county upon the Sect. Treasurer there.
I have the honor sir to be your obediently H. A. Williams.
Copy
Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, February 21, 1894.
Hon. H. A. Williams, Secretary of the Treasury, Republic of Liberia.

Dear Sir: Receiving to our interview in reference to the claim of the Estate of Mr. A. M. Miller against your Government, I beg to say, I have in my possession $598.15, in Maryland County obligations, and I will be glad, if you can settle these or advise me what course to pursue to cause an early settlement of same, as his widow is very much in need of the money.
I have the honor to be, Sir, your obedient Servant, Beverly Y. Payne. U.S. Vice Consul General.
Copy
Madame, I am in receipt of your favor of the 11th ult., inclosing ($15.00) Fifteen dollars in Liberian Currency and soliciting my services in settling your late husband's estate.

I beg to say that your Liberian Government fills are in my possession, and will have my attention as soon as the affairs at Cape Palmas (in here they are payable) will warrant. I shall sell the Liberian Currency ($15.00) for what it will bring in the market, and remit you at an early date.
I have the honor to be, Madame, your ob't Servant, Beverly Y. Payne. U.S.V.C.G.
Copy
Legation of the U.S.A. Monrovia, Liberia, April 24, 1893.
Honorable G. W. Gibson, Secretary of State, Monrovia, Liberia.

Sir: As I shall probably leave this post at no distant day it becomes my duty to make a report upon all unfinished business, and this in time that my Government may further instruct me before I take my departure in case further instruction be necessary. In accordance herewtih I respectfully ask a report upon each of the following subjects numbered 1, 2 and 3:-
1. The Treasury claims against Maryland County, belonging to the Estate of Capt. A. M. Miller, deceased.
See my communication No. 19 leaing date, Dec. 5, 1892.) (over)

2. The destruction of the Baptist Vic Mission at Bendon. There is hardly a probability of any more goods being uncovered and it seems to me all that is necessary now is for your Government to determine the responsibility encumbent upon it, on that it will assume.
3. Whether or not our Government may expect a reduction in Postal Rates between Liberia and the United States, and if so, where? If not, why?
Hoping that these subjects shall receive your earliest attention, I have the honor to be, Sir,--
Your obedient servant, William D. McCoy, U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General.
Copy
Treasury Department, Monrovia, Jan'y 4, 1893.
Hon'ble W. D. McCoy, U.S. Minister &c
Sir, I beg to acknowledge receipt of your note enclosing order for $50, on account of late Capt. Miller.
I retain same and will give same attention by arranging the payment of yours &c. H. A> Williams, Sec'y Treas'ry.
Copy
Treasury Department Secretary of the Treasury.
Republic of Liberia, Monrovia, Jan'y 4, 1893.
Hon'ble W. D. McCoy, U.S. Minister &c Monrovia
Sir, Agreeably with my note of this morning, I beg to enclose check in payment of the order you presented on account Estate of the late Capt. Miller.
Yours &c H. A. Williams. Sec'y Treasury.
Copy
Legation of the U. S. A. Monrovia, Liberia, March, 25, 1893.
Mrs. A. M. Miller, Newcastle, Maine.

Madame:- Affairs at Cape Palmas are in such an unsettled condition, that it is impossible to tell when the Treasurer will be able to cash those orders belonging to the Estate of your deceased husband. I have than on hand and shall do what is possible to get them cashed before I leave this post. In case I am not successful I shall turn the Orders over to my successor, take his respect for the same and forward a copy of the receipt to you.
I have collected one Government order of $50.00 2/3 being

being paid in current money and 1/3 in Liberian currency. The law authorizes such payment although the currency is almost worthless. I am obliged to send it to you for I cannot dispose of it. Occasionally one can get 50Â¢ on a dollar for it but it is seldom that there is any demand for it at all.
Please acknowledge the receipt of this directing your letter to me to the Department of State, Washington, D. C. If I shall have left Monrovia it will be kept there for me.
Very respectfully yours, William D. McCoy U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General
(over)
Statement
Missionary Drafts & U. S. Currency Collected... $33.33 1/3 Liberian Currency ,, 16.66 2/3 Total_ _ _ _ $50.00 Less 5% for collecting & expenses... 2.50 Amoung due...$47.50
Drafts and U.S. Currency inclosed...$32.00 Liberian ,, ,, 15.50 Amount... $47.50
William D. McCoy, U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General.
Legation of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, Dec. 5, 1892.
Honorable G. W. Gibson, Sec. of State of the Republic of Liberia.

Sir: This will respecfully inform you, that I have Treasury Order on the Treasurer of Maryland County, Liberia, amounting in value to the sum of Five Hundred Ninety Eight and 15/100 Dollars ($598 15/100) belonging to the Estate of Captain A. M. Miller late of Cape Palmas but now deceased.

I respectfully request that the proper Officials be instructed to arrange with your department that you may make a settlement at your earliest convenience, that I may close up the affairs pertaining to the estate.
Inclosed find a list of Registered Number together with amounts of credits and dues. (See page 78 & 79 [see in closure No. 1, Oct 31, 1892]).
I am, sir, your obedient servant, William D. McCoy, U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General.
Copy
Legation of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, Oct. 31, 1892.
E. Warneke Esq., Cape Palmas, Liberia,
Sir: THis is to acknowledge the receipt from you, through Mr. Hoenigeberg of the following Orders belonging to the Estate of the late Captain A. M. Miller:-
Treasury Orders
Continued over.
Treasury Orders.
One General Gov't Order (no. 40) 50.
Summary
You will see by the above that the Treasury Orders = $1001.75 Less Credits 403.60 Balance due 598.15 instead of $599.55 as you made it.
Am very much obliged for your information regarding Mr. James Bowie.
With best wishes for your health and properity, I remain your very truly, William D. McCoy, U.S. Minister Resident & Consul General.
Transcript From the Acts of the Legation of Liberia Session of 1893-94. Section I. Pgs 9 & 10.

Sec. 1. That immediately after the passage of this Resolution, the Secretary of the Treasury is directed to exchange the currency on hand in the Treasury Department for redemption of Bonds of 1880, and payment of interest upon the same, or he shall sell the same to the highest bidder, for County audited bills of any county within this Republic, as well as all other currency in any of the Sub Treasurer's office of this Republic, shall be those disposed of as above recited; and that the Act passed dining the session of 1892-3, authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to issue these percent gold bonds in exchange

exchange for deposits of Liberian Currency, be and the same is hereby extended until September 30th, 1895. All currency taken in for exchange of gold bonds within that time shall be incuded in the provisions of this Joint Resolution.
Any law to the contrary notwithstanding. APproved January 13th, 1894.
